questions.neutral: Did you walk the long way?

hobby.message: You bring something banned books with you again?
I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.
Origami helping you dodge the spiral?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah, I took the long route. Less crowded that way.
Needed some air after today.
I fold origami—just paper, nothing official.
People wanted me to join the Redemption thing. Not my style.
Took a different path—just to avoid the big groups.
I got pushed into that community challenge for origami. Uncomfortable.
Folding’s usually just for myself, a way to focus.
Now the block wants cranes and displays for points.
Feels strange doing it on command.
Walked past the square. Too loud with all the Redemption crowds.
Origami helps me slow my thoughts. I bring scrap paper from work sometimes.
Usually I fold dragons or modular pieces—keeps my hands busy.
This week, people kept asking me to fold for the block challenge.
It’s odd sharing a hobby that’s always been private.
I just want the quiet back, to be honest.
Yeah, I avoided the main road. Groups stressed about the challenge.
I’ve folded origami since college—complex models, not the showy kind.
Lately it’s been cranes and flowers, since everyone wants to score points.
They called me the expert, but I just needed to think.
Folding used to be how I handled stress... now it stirs things up.
Last night, folding for the block, I sort of missed being invisible.
It makes me wonder if the game even helps anyone relax.
Yes, I took the long path, needed to clear my head after that block meeting.
I’m obsessed with origami—used to hide in the archive room and fold.
Last week, when the Redemption Games hit, I got pulled into leading a group build.
We used recycled forms—old ration slips, policy memos. I never fold with new paper.
People thought it was fun, but it made me nervous, seeing my private routine become collective.
It’s the only thing that keeps me steady when the system spirals.
Now, every time I fold for points, it feels less like mine.
Can’t help thinking Halden would hate how performative it is now.
hobby_answer: A few cranes, yes. Nothing... elaborate lately.
People expect group projects now. Makes things less quiet.
With the block games, origami isn't really private anymore.
Harder to clear my head when everyone's watching.
I stick to simple folds for now.
Yeah. Folded a couple cranes, basic stuff.
The Redemption Games got everyone folding—they say it counts as cooperation.
Feels odd, sharing something so personal with the block.
Most people just want the BCI points, not the craft.
Every fold feels... inspected. Less peaceful lately.
I finish quick, keep my own scraps aside.
Plenty of cranes, actually. Used old ration slips—they're sturdier than receipts.
The 'shared art' challenge for Redemption Games made everyone want to fold together.
I helped. Taught people the base folds—cranes, lilies, even a modular cube.
It was strange, seeing origami treated like a quota to fill, not a puzzle to solve.
Usually I use it to focus, clear looping thoughts. Now it feels performative.
Still, some folks surprised me. Ilona folded a near-perfect pegasus on her second try.
But honestly, I miss folding alone.
Yes, cranes and a couple dragons, though the dragons take patience I can't find lately.
After the games started, the block turned my hobby into a public event.
We all folded at the table for 'community points'—not because they cared about tradition.
I used to fold to manage tension. Now people critique my style, count output.
It’s less meditation, more performance. I don't love that, but it kept us from arguing about rations, at least.
Ilona asked for a Ryujin demonstration. I faked an easy one—my hands wouldn’t stop shaking.
It's strange losing something private to a collective rule.
I keep scraps to myself. It helps me remember why I began.
Lots of cranes. Used to do complex creatures, but simple folds keep my mind steady.
Folding started as a way to control anxious spirals—me, paper, silence, that was enough.
Then the Redemption Games turned it into a group task. Suddenly, technique doesn’t matter—output does.
Neighbors who never spoke before are at my door with paper scraps, asking for lessons. I don't blame them. Everyone's desperate for access again.
It’s bittersweet—my routine invaded, but I saw Ilona smile for the first time in weeks.
Still, every fold feels surveilled, like the system is judging intention, not skill.
Sometimes I sneak off to fold alone in the stairwell. Quietest place left.
Even origami’s a compliance test now. Hard to trust the purpose, harder to not take part.
I miss feeling invisible. Now I wonder what Halden would say about all this.
